profileText: A Representative from Georgia; born in Savannah, Ga., in 1788; educated in England; held several local offices; solicitor general from November 1816 to September 1817, when he resigned; member of the Georgia state house of representatives in 1818 and 1819; elected as a Republican to the Seventeenth Congress, reelected as a Crawford Republican to the Eighteenth Congress, and elected as a Jacksonian to the Nineteenth and Twentieth Congresses and served from March 4, 1821, until his resignation in 1827 before the convening of the Twentieth Congress; never served in the Twentieth Congress; first captain of the Savannah Volunteer Guards; died in Savannah, Chatham County, Ga., November 21, 1832; interment in Bonaventure Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In File II Names.
researchRecord.description: File is primarily incoming correspondence to the Governor of Georgia. Finding aid in repository.

recordLocation.name: Georgia Department of Archives and History

researchRecord.name: 1819, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edward Fenwick Tattnall to James Hunter written on April 13, 1819. In the letter, Tattnall writes that he is resigning as a Director of a branch Bank of the United States.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the George Michael Troup Letter, 1824, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter to Governor Troup from Edward F. Tattnall written on December 5, 1824. In the letter, Tattnall indicates that Lafayette's trip South will be postponed until after the inauguration of the president.

parentRecordLocation.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
